qas.question: What is speed limit for railways?
Why is DC motor being used more than AC type?
What are two types of railway transportation still use DC motor?
What must operate at constant speeds?
Speed was controlled by disconnecting the traction motors where?
A brush-type BC motor operated at what speeds?
All early electrified motors used what type of motor?
Varying the transition motors' fields helped control what?

context: <b3_0>Railways<b3_0/> must operate at <a0_0><b5_0>variable<b5_0/> speeds<a0_0/>. Until the mid 1980s this was only practical with the brush-type DC motor, although such DC can be supplied from an AC catenary via on-board electric power conversion. Since such <a1_0>conversion was not well developed<a1_0/> in the late 19th century and early 20th century, most early electrified railways used <b6_0>DC<b6_0/> and many still do, particularly <a2_0>rapid transit (subways) and trams<a2_0/>. <b7_0>Speed<b7_0/> was controlled by connecting the traction motors <b4_0>in various series-parallel combinations<b4_0/>, by varying the traction motors' fields, and by inserting and removing starting resistances to limit motor current.
